title: Machine Learning Model Design from a Sociotechnical Systems Perspective

context.prior_knowledge: Basic machine learning and statistical knowledge, along with programming experience
context.additional_context: Students Design Machine Learning Models to Solve Real-World Social Problems, Developing Integrated Analysis Skills for Techno-Social Interactions. Team Projects Use Collaboration Tools (Zoom, Miro, GitHub) in a BYOD Environment

learning_goals: Learners analyze at least three real-world data science cases (e.g., medical diagnostic models, financial risk assessment models) and document in a 5-page report how a data scientistâ€™s subjectivity influences model design (feature selection, evaluation metrics, hyperparameters). They achieve an "Excellent" grade in at least two of the three peer evaluation rubric items: clarity, analytical depth, and practicality.
Identify at least three social factors to consider when designing a machine learning system tailored to a specific sociocultural context (language processing).

Learners analyze given AI project outputs (model predictions, data distributions) to visualize model explainability using at least two techniques (e.g., SHAP/LIME), propose at least three bias management strategies at the data preprocessing/model design stages, and compile findings into a report within 10 pages.

resources: Authentic Language Dataset (e.g., Text Data Related to Social Phenomena)

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
